I'd also add that I don't know what implementation of NEAT you're using, =
but it would be a good idea first to validate that the version you have wor=
ks on a common benchmark that NEAT is known to solve like XOR.  The point w=
ould not be to obtain optimal performance, but just to make sure it solves =
the problem at all.  If it doesn't, then you know the problem is not with M=
ountain Car in particular, but something else in the setup of NEAT.

ken

-=

> Hi,
> 
> Although I haven=
't tried NEAT on the mountain car problem, I'd like to comment that it can =
be solved without having any hidden nodes in the controller (at least the s=
tandard version of the problem). I've tried that by evolving a policy (not =
a value function) using (1+1)-CMA-ES and noticed that solutions are found v=
ery quickly.=C2=A0
> 
> Best,
> Vassilis
> 
> 
> 
> On Wed, Dec 19, 2012 at=
 3:33 PM, ivalcky <ivalcky@...> wrote:
> 
>  
> >=C2=A0 
> >Hi, everyone, I=
 have a problem about neat.
> >I applied NEAT to the mountain car problem, =
and I found the result is bad. I want to find out why.
> >Here are some pos=
silbility I am thinking of. Can anyone give me any hints and comments.
> >T=
he first possibility I thought is the weak ability of the initial populatio=
n, since there are no hidden nodes, the neural network can not approximate =
the value function well. In my experiment, it can not achieve the top after=
 10000 steps. 
> >Another reason I considered is the initial weights of the=
 neural network, learning rate and so on, these parameters should be set ca=
refully, but it takes me a long time, and I haven't found a better setting.=

> >I also think the mutation rate is an important factor.If I set a small =
mutation rate, it may take a longer time to envolve. If I set a bigger valu=
e, does this lead to divergence?
> >
> >Any feedback is appreciated.
> >
> =
>
